items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.

We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.67 mAOD at 05:30 on 02/10/23 and 4.75 mAOD at 17:15 on 02/10/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 20 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 02/10/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels are expected to remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent rainfall.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
Lake levels remain high at the Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 02/10/2023.

items.description: River Alt, Formby to Huyton
items.message: The Flood Alert has now been removed. River levels are now falling on the River Alt following rain overnight 30/09/2023 into Sunday morning 1/10/2023.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Monday afternoon's tide at 14:15 on 02/10/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light Easterly Force 3 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.1 m. The total forecast tide is 6.22 metres Chart Datum (3.17 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. The tide levels remain a little elevated over the next 2 days. This may cause some impacts at each high water until Wednesday‚ but where impacts do occur‚ they will be very minor. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 17:00 on 02/10/2023.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (02/10/2023). Flooding is possible at The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point on Monday 02/10/2023 from 6:30AM to 9:15AM. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10am on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 7:45am and 9:45am tomorrow morning, Monday 2 October.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  5.06mAODN at 8:45am, on Monday 2 October, which is 0.35m above tide tables, wind Force 2, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Monday at 9:30pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 2 October

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 7:45am and 9:45am tomorrow morning, Monday 2 October.  Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  5.06mAODN at 8:45am, on Monday 2 October, which is 0.35m above tide tables, wind Force 2, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Monday at 9:30pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 2 October

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast early Monday morning on 02/10/2023.

Flooding to low lying land, beaches, roads and footpaths is possible between 04:42 AM and 06:42 AM on Monday 02/10/2023.

Areas of particular risk include Alnmouth river footpath and Alnmouth horse field.

Tide levels are expected to be higher than usual due to the high spring tides. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Please stay away from low lying land, roads, riverside footpaths and coastal footpaths as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 12:00PM 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides, levels will be at their highest this evening at 08:00 PM on 1/10/2023. The forecast high water level is 2.47m.
Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit.
Flooding is possible at West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit between 06:45 PM and 10:00 PM on 1/10/2023.
The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We are closely monitoring the situation remotely during the high water with duty staff on standby to react as required. 
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 2/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: High water levels are forecast to affect the foreshore from Ramsgate to Kingsdown tomorrow afternoon, Monday 02/10/2023, as a result of high spring tides. Tides will be at their highest between 12:00 and 13:00 tomorrow, Monday 02/10/2023, with high tide at 12:30. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea and low lying land along the tidal Stour. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and our partners and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes. For those that use it, the astronomical water level will be 3.39m AOD and the total water level will be 3.63m AOD.

items.description: Coast from St Margaret's at Cliffe to Sandgate
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: High water levels are forecast to affect the foreshore from St Margaret’s at Cliffe to Sandgate tomorrow afternoon, Monday 02/10/2023, as a result of high spring tides. Tides will be at their highest between 12:00 and 13:00 tomorrow, Monday 02/10/2023, with high tide at 12:30. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. For those that use it, the astronomical water level will be 3.39m AOD and the total water level will be 3.63m AOD.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1:30pm and 3:30pm this afternoon, Monday 2nd October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.50mAODN at 2:30pm, on Monday 2nd October, which is 0.15m above tide tables, wind Force 3, southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The current series of high spring tides is reaching its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 4pm today, Monday 2nd October.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 1:30pm and 3:30pm this afternoon, Monday 2nd October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.50mAODN at 2:30pm, on Monday 2nd October, which is 0.15m above tide tables, wind Force 3, southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).   The current series of high spring tides is reaching its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 4pm today.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 1:30pm and 3:30pm this afternoon, Monday 2nd October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.91mAODN at 2:30pm, on Monday 2nd October, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind Force 3, southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).   The current series of high spring tides is reaching its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 4pm today.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur tomorrow morning due to high tides between 7:45am and 9:45am, Monday 2nd October.  We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.90mAODN at 08:45am, Monday 2nd October, which is 0.34m above tide tables, wind Force 2, south westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide table). The tide on Monday 2nd October at 9:30pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11:00am tomorrow, Monday 2nd October.

items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur tomorrow morning due to high tides between 7:45am and 9:45am, Monday 2nd October. High tides will mean flood gates will be closed restricting normal access to beaches around Eccles on Sea, and Sea Palling. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.21 mAODN at 08:45am, Monday 2nd October, which is 0.46m above tide tables, wind Force 2, south - westerly. We will update this message by 11:00am tomorrow, Monday 2nd October.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur tomorrow morning due to high tides between 10:45am and 12:45 midday, Monday 2nd October.  We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.70mAODN at 11:45am, Monday 2nd October, which is 0.31m above tide tables, wind Force 3, south - westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide table). The tide on Tuesday 3rd October at 12:30 midnight is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 2:00pm tomorrow, Monday 2nd October.

Flooding is possible at The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall between 6:45AM and 9:15AM on 02/10/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. This message will be updated by 10am on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
This flood alert remains in place as a result of high spring tides until tomorrow evening 02/10/2023.

Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.

Forecast high water at 21:30 this evening is at a level of 7.86 mAOD with a Force 3 westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply up to one hour either side of the high tide. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible but properties are not expected to flood. We have closed flood gates at Pill and Shirehampton and are monitoring the situation.

This flood alert will be updated on Monday 02/10/23.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message: As a result of high spring tides, flooding of roads and farmland is possible on the high tides at 9:30pm today, 01/09/23 and 9:45am tomorrow, 02/10/23. A series of high tides is due over the weekend peaking yesterday evening Saturday, 01/10/23. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 8.0m at 9:30pm this evening, 01/10/23 and 7.3 to 7.6m at 10:00am tomorrow morning, 02/10/23. Newport 7.2 to 7.5m at 9:30pm this evening, 01/10/23 and 7.1 to 7.3m at 9:45am tomorrow morning, 02/10/23. This mornings tidal peaks, Sunday, 01/10/23 were:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.63m and Newport 7.29m. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 2pm on Monday 02/10/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force for the high tide forecast at 2:15am on Tuesday 03/10/2023.  The high tide at lunchtime on Monday 02/10/2023 at 2:00pm is not expected to reach threshold.  Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 3:00pm on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the next 5 high tides, until after the hide tide of Sunday evening 1st of October. High water at Ilfracombe is at 18:56 Friday 29th September, 0718 and 19:38 on Saturday 30th September and 07:57 and 20:18 on Sunday 1st October, times of high water will vary along the coast. The tides will be peak for high tide of Saturday evening.
Strong force 6, southerly winds are forecast to cause sea spray in exposed coastal locations.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide levels at Ilfracombe are over 5 metres across the next 5 high tides with a peak of 5.32m for the evening high tide of Saturday 30th September mAOD.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
This flood alert remains in force today, Sunday 01/10/23, due to continuing high spring tides. The forecast high water tonight is at 20:30 with a level of 7.86 mAOD and a Force 3 westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding is possible for the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade. Flooding to roads and low-lying land is possible at this time, however conditions may apply for a period either side of the high tide. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.

This current sequence of spring tides has now peaked however tide levels remain high. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. We are monitoring the situation closely, and this message will be updated by midday on Monday 02/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 01:30 AM on 02/10/2023.
Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston and Sandside.
No property flooding is expected.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next two days and as a result we may issue further alerts.
We are have closed flood gates in the area.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 02/10/2023.

items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in place due to the high tides forecast from early Monday morning on 02/10/2023.

Flooding to low lying land, roads and footpaths is possible between 04:42 AM and 06:42 AM on Monday 02/10/2023. Areas most at risk include from Wylam to the North Sea coast, including Watergate Car Park at Newcastle Quayside.

Tide levels are expected to be higher than usual due to the high spring tides. The early morning tide for Monday is also forecast to be higher than usual, and therefore we expect this alert to remain in force over the weekend. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Keadby river gauge as a result of high spring tides and strong winds causing a tidal surge. Flooding is expected on high tides at 09:15 AM on 02/10/2023 at Keadby. Areas most at risk are Keadby, Amcotts, Owston, Burringham, Gunness, Althorpe, East Butterwick, Flixborough, Gunness Lane and, Neap House road. We expect river levels to peak on the high tide at 09:45 AM on 02/10/2023 at Keadby. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.9 to 4.0m on Sunday afternoon, 01/10/2023; Cae Howel 1.8 to 2.1m Sunday evening, 01/10/2023.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
  
This message will be updated  by 14:00 on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Haverigg
items.message:
The Flood Alert has now been removed. 
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.

items.description: King's Lynn, West Lynn and The Wash frontage in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 7:45am and 9:45am tomorrow morning, Monday 2 October.  Areas most at risk are King's Lynn, West Lynn, Clenchwarton, Terrington St Clement, Walpole Cross Keys and Tilney All Saints. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  5.06mAODN at 8:45am, on Monday 2 October, which is 0.35m above tide tables, wind Force 2, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Monday at 9:30pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 2 October

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels will rise on the River Ouse due to high astronomical tides. Flooding is possible at the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas between 10:30 AM and 11:30 AM on 02/10/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10am on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington - South Pier
items.message: High spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (02/10/2023). Flooding is possible from The South Pier and Chicken Run Jetty, and adjacent car parks off South Cliff Road at 06:30 to 07:30 on 02/10/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10am on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea and River Esk at Whitby Harbour
items.message: High spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (02/10/2023). Flooding is possible along Whitby harbour area including Abrahams Quay, Pier Road, New Quay Road, Church Street, Campion Dock and Bagdale Road at 06:15 to 06:45 on 02/10/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10am on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet
items.message: High spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (02/10/2023). Flooding is possible at The Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet at 08:00 to 09:45 on 02/10/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10am on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington - Harbour Road and Floral Pavilion
items.message: High spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (02/10/2023). Flooding is possible from The north side of the dock area, properties on Harbour Road and the Floral Pavilion at 06:30 to 07:30 on 02/10/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10am on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Gainsborough river gauge as a result of high spring tides and strong winds causing a tidal surge. Flooding is possible with peak high tides at 11:00 AM on 02/10/2023 and 11:30 AM 03/10/2023 at Gainsborough and 12:00 PM at Torksey on 02/10/2023. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road and Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, Trent Wharfage and Gainsborough Railway Bridge. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank of the Humber estuary from Kilnsea to Skeffling and Weeton
items.message: The high spring tide period has now passed and we do not expect to see such high water levels over the coming days. Flood Alerts may remain in some places along the coast for the next couple of days, where overtopping waves and wind blown spray may affect exposed frontages on Tuesday morning.

items.description: North Bank of the Humber estuary at Hessle Haven
items.message: High spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (02/10/2023). Flooding is possible along the Hessle area around Hessle Haven areas at 08:00 to 09:15 on 02/10/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10am on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Alkborough Flats
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Keadby river gauge as a result of high spring tides and strong winds causing a tidal surge. Flooding is expected on high tides at 09:15 AM on 02/10/2023 at Keadby. The area most at risk is the Alkborough Flats. The Keadby river gauge is forecast to overtop the lower spillway and result in flooding. We expect river levels to peak on the high tide at 09:45 AM on 02/10/2023 at Keadby. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham
items.message: The Flood Alert has now been removed. High tides are no longer expected to reach threshold.

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Whitton to South Ferriby
items.message: Spring tides will lead to unusually high tidal levels along The South Humber Bank, between Whitton and South Ferriby on Monday morning. The time and date of the forecast high water at South Ferriby is 08:45 AM on 02/10/2023, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of this. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn’t likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads, as sea spray and waves can be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn’t likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. items.description: The north Norfolk coast at Salthouse and east Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur tomorrow morning due to high tides between 7:45am and 9:45am, Monday 2nd October.  Areas most at risk are Coast Road in Salthouse and, Coast Road in Cley. Flooding is also expected for Salthouse and Cley marshes. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.90mAODN at 08:45am, Monday 2nd October, which is 0.34m above tide tables, wind Force 2, south - westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide table). The tide on Monday 2nd October at 9:30pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11:00am tomorrow, Monday 2nd October.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast at Wells Quay
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur tomorrow morning due to high tides between 7:45am and 9:45am, Monday 2nd October.  Areas most at risk are The Quay, East End and roads joining the Quay between the Flood Barrier and East End including, Unns Yard, Jicklings Yard, Staithe Street, Croft Yard and Standard Street. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.90mAODN at 08:45am, Monday 2nd October, which is 0.34m above tide tables, wind Force 2, south - westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide table).  The tide on Monday 2nd October at 9:30pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11:00am tomorrow, Monday 2nd October.

items.description: Tidal River Aire catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: This alert is issued for the high tide between 09:00 and 10:00 on 2 October for the tidal River Aire between Hirst Courtney and Airmyn. One of the the highest tides of the year is expected on the Lower Aire and water may spill onto areas of lower lying land adjacent to the river as the tide peaks. There is no indication of that flooding of property will occur. These particularly high tides are part of the naturally occurring astronomical tide cycle during the year. High water levels may persist for several hours either side of high tide. Our Operational teams will be in the area checking flood defences and banks along the river during the morning of 2 October. This message will be updated by 7:30 AM on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

One of the the highest tides of the year is expected and water may spill onto areas of lower lying land adjacent to the estuary as the tide peaks. There is no indication of that flooding of property will occur. These particularly high tides are part of the naturally occurring astronomical tide cycle during the year. High water levels may apply several hours either side of high tide. Our Operational teams will be in the area checking flood defences and banks along the river during the morning of 2 October. This message will be updated by 7:30am on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes
